While individuals have the choice to use performance-enhancing drugs, the consequences of doping extend far beyond the person using them.

Firstly, using performance-enhancing drugs undermines the integrity and fairness of sports. Athletes should be competing based on their natural athletic abilities; doping creates an unfair advantage for those who choose to use these substances.

Secondly, allowing doping would perpetuate a dangerous precedent, leading to a "win at all costs" mentality and pressuring athletes to take ever-increasing amounts and types of drugs to stay competitive. This could lead to serious, long-term health consequences for athletes, particularly younger ones who are still growing and developing.

Lastly, permitting doping in sports sends a harmful message to society, undermining the values of hard work, dedication, and perseverance that sports are meant to teach. If athletes are allowed to use performance-enhancing substances to gain a competitive edge, it sends the message that cheating is acceptable as long as the desired outcome is achieved.
